faq.question: Is this image resizer really Free?
faq.answer: Yes! Our image resizer is 100% Free with no hidden fees, watermarks, or account requirements. You can resize unlimited images.

faq.question: Are my images uploaded to your servers?
faq.answer: No! All image processing happens directly in your browser using Canvas API technology. Your images never leave your device, ensuring complete privacy.

faq.question: What's the maximum file size I can resize?
faq.answer: You can resize images up to 25MB. This limit is based on browser memory, not our servers (since we don't use servers for processing).

faq.question: Can I resize images for Instagram?
faq.answer: Absolutely! We have presets for Instagram Posts (1080x1080), Instagram Stories (1080x1920), and all major social media platforms.

faq.question: Will resizing reduce image quality?
faq.answer: When you downsize images (make them smaller), quality remAIns excellent. Upsizing can introduce softness - for AI-powered upscaling with quality enhancement, try our AIimageupscaler.

faq.question: What formats can I export?
faq.answer: You can export as JPEG ( for photos), PNG ( for graphics with transparency), or WebP ( for web optimization).

faq.question: How do I mAIntAIn aspect ratio when resizing?
faq.answer: Enable the 'MAIntAIn aspect ratio' toggle. When active, changing width automatically adjusts height proportionally (and vice versa).

faq.question: Can I batch resize multiple images?
faq.answer: Currently, you can resize one image at a time. For batch processing and advanced AI enhancement, check out our premium AIimageupscaler.

faq.question: What size should Instagram posts be?
faq.answer: Instagram posts are at 1080x1080 pixels (square), 1080x1350 (portrAIt), or 1080x566 (landscape). Square posts at 1080x1080 get the most consistent display.

faq.question: What size are Instagram Stories?
faq.answer: Instagram Stories should be 1080x1920 pixels (9:16 aspect ratio) to fill the entire screen without cropping.

faq.question: Will resizing reduce my image quality?
faq.answer: Our tool uses high-quality algorithms to minimize quality loss. For results, start with images larger than your target size.

faq.question: Can I resize for Instagram Reels?
faq.answer: Yes! Instagram Reels use the same 1080x1920 (9:16) dimensions as Stories.

faq.question: What size should YouTube thumbnAIls be?
faq.answer: YouTube recommends 1280x720 pixels with a 16:9 aspect ratio. Minimum width is 640 pixels, and the file must be under 2MB.

faq.question: What format is for YouTube thumbnAIls?
faq.answer: YouTube accepts JPG, GIF, and PNG. JPEG is recommended for photos as it provides good quality at smaller file sizes.

faq.question: Why is 1280x720 the recommended size?
faq.answer: 1280x720 is the minimum that displays well across all devices while matching YouTube's 16:9 player aspect ratio.

faq.question: Will my thumbnAIl look good on all devices?
faq.answer: Yes! 1280x720 thumbnAIls scale perfectly to all screen sizes, from mobile phones to 4K TVs.

faq.question: What size should Facebook posts be?
faq.answer: Facebook recommends 1200x630 pixels for shared images and link previews. This size displays well in the news feed across all devices.

faq.question: What size is a Facebook cover photo?
faq.answer: Facebook cover photos should be 820x312 pixels for pages, or 851x315 for personal profiles. Mobile displays may crop slightly differently.

faq.question: What's the format for Facebook images?
faq.answer: JPEG is for photos, PNG for graphics with text or transparency. Facebook compresses images, so start with high quality.

faq.question: Why do my images look blurry on Facebook?
faq.answer: Facebook compresses uploaded images. Use our tool to resize to exact dimensions and export at high quality to minimize compression artifacts.

faq.question: What size should Twitter images be?
faq.answer: Twitter recommends 1200x675 pixels (16:9 ratio) for single images in tweets. This size displays without cropping on most devices.

faq.question: What size is a Twitter header?
faq.answer: Twitter headers should be 1500x500 pixels. Note that parts of the header may be covered by your profile picture.

faq.question: Does Twitter compress images?
faq.answer: Yes, Twitter compresses images. Use high-quality exports (90%+) and exact dimensions to minimize compression artifacts.

faq.question: What's the maximum image size on Twitter?
faq.answer: Twitter allows images up to 5MB for photos. GIFs can be up to 15MB. Our tool helps you stay within these limits.

faq.question: How many images can I resize at once?
faq.answer: You can process up to 20 images in a single batch. This limit ensures optimal browser while still providing significant time savings.

faq.question: Is the Bulk Image Resizer really Free?
faq.answer: Yes! Our Bulk Image Resizer is 100% Free with unlimited batches. No watermarks, , no hidden fees.

faq.question: Are my images uploaded to your servers?
faq.answer: No! All image processing happens directly in your browser using the Canvas API. Your images never leave your device, ensuring complete privacy.

faq.question: What's the difference between 'fit' and 'fill' modes?
faq.answer: Fit mode resizes images to fit within your dimensions while preserving aspect ratio (images may be smaller than target). Fill mode crops images to fill exact dimensions, which may remove some content from the edges.

faq.question: Will all my images look the same size?
faq.answer: When 'MAIntAIn aspect ratio' is enabled with 'fit' mode, images will be proportional but may have different final dimensions. For exact uniform sizing, use 'fill' mode or uncheck aspect ratio.

faq.question: Can I download images individually?
faq.answer: Yes! After processing, you can download each image individually or download all at once as a ZIP file for convenience.

faq.question: What formats can I convert to?
faq.answer: You can output resized images as JPEG ( for photos), PNG ( for graphics), or WebP ( for web optimization).

faq.question: Can I remove an image from the batch?
faq.answer: Yes! You can remove individual images from the batch before or after processing by clicking the X button next to each image.

faq.question: How much can I compress an image?
faq.answer: Typically, you can reduce file sizes by 60-80% without noticeable quality loss. Results vary based on the image content and your quality settings. Photos compress better than graphics with lots of detAIl.

faq.question: Will compression reduce image quality?
faq.answer: Compression involves a trade-off between file size and quality. At 70-80% quality settings, most people cannot see the difference. Our tool lets you preview and adjust the quality level before downloading.

faq.question: What's the format for compression?
faq.answer: WebP offers the compression with great quality, but isn't universally supported. JPEG is for photos and has excellent browser support. PNG is lossless but creates larger files.

faq.question: Is there a file size limit?
faq.answer: You can compress images up to 25MB. This limit is based on browser memory, not server restrictions (since we don't upload to servers).

faq.question: Can I batch compress multiple images?
faq.answer: Currently, you can compress one image at a time. For batch processing and advanced features, check out our premium AIimageupscaler which includes compression.

faq.question: What quality setting should I use?
faq.answer: For web use, 70-80% is optimal. For printing or use, 85-95%. For maximum compression (like emAIl), 60-70% works well.

faq.question: Why convert PNG to JPG?
faq.answer: JPG files are much smaller than PNG for photos and complex images. PNG is for graphics with transparency or text, while JPG is better for photographs, reducing file sizes by 70-90%.

faq.question: What happens to transparent backgrounds?
faq.answer: JPG doesn't support transparency. Our tool lets you choose a background color (white, black, or custom) to fill transparent areas. This gives you full control over the final appearance.

faq.question: Will I lose quality converting PNG to JPG?
faq.answer: PNG is lossless, while JPG uses compression. At 85-95% quality settings, quality loss is minimal and usually imperceptible. The file size savings are worth the tiny quality trade-off for most uses.

faq.question: Can I convert JPG back to PNG?
faq.answer: Yes! Our format converter also handles JPG to PNG conversion. However, converting JPG to PNG won't recover transparency or improve quality - it just changes the format.

faq.question: What quality setting should I use?
faq.answer: For web and social media, 80-85% is perfect. For printing or use, 90-95%. For maximum file size reduction, 70-75% still looks good.

faq.question: Why convert JPG to PNG?
faq.answer: PNG offers lossless quality and transparency support. It's ideal for graphics, logos, images that need editing, or when you need to preserve exact image quality without additional compression.

faq.question: Will converting improve my JPG quality?
faq.answer: Converting won't improve existing JPEG compression artifacts, but it will prevent any additional quality loss. The image will look the same but in a lossless format.

faq.question: Will the file size increase?
faq.answer: Yes, PNG files are typically larger than JPG because PNG is lossless. Expect 2-5x larger files for photographs. This is the trade-off for lossless quality.

faq.question: Can I add transparency after converting?
faq.answer: Yes! Once in PNG format, you can use image editing software to remove backgrounds and add transparency. JPG doesn't support transparency.

faq.question: Why convert WebP to JPG?
faq.answer: WebP is a modern format not supported everywhere. JPG works on all devices, in all emAIl clients, and with all software - it's the universal standard.

faq.question: What happens to WebP transparency?
faq.answer: JPG doesn't support transparency. Our tool lets you choose a background color (white, black, or custom) to fill transparent areas.

faq.question: Will file size increase?
faq.answer: Usually, yes. WebP typically offers better compression than JPG. Expect files to be 20-50% larger, but with guaranteed compatibility.

faq.question: Can I convert animated WebP?
faq.answer: Converting animated WebP will capture the first frame as a static JPG. For animated images, consider GIF format instead.

faq.question: Why convert WebP to PNG?
faq.answer: PNG offers better software compatibility than WebP while preserving transparency. It's ideal for editing, older software, or when you need a lossless format.

faq.question: Will transparency be preserved?

faq.question: Will file size increase?

faq.question: Which is better: PNG or JPG from WebP?
faq.answer: Use PNG if you need transparency or lossless quality for editing. Use JPG for smaller files and universal compatibility when transparency isn't needed.

faq.question: Why convert JPG to WebP?
faq.answer: WebP offers 25-35% smaller files than JPG at the same visual quality. This means faster website loading, lower bandwidth costs, and better user experience.

faq.question: Is WebP supported everywhere?
faq.answer: WebP is supported by all modern browsers (Chrome, Firefox, Safari, Edge) covering over 95% of users. For older browsers, consider serving JPG as a fallback.

faq.question: How much smaller will my files be?
faq.answer: Typically, WebP files are 25-35% smaller than equivalent JPG files. A 1MB JPG might become 650-750KB as WebP with identical visual quality.

faq.question: Should I use WebP for all my images?
faq.answer: For web use, yes! WebP is ideal for websites. For emAIl, printing, or older software, JPG may be more compatible.

faq.question: How many images can I compress at once?
faq.answer: You can compress up to 20 images at once. This limit ensures optimal browser while providing efficient batch processing.

faq.question: What's the difference between quality and target size modes?
faq.answer: quality mode (1-100%) gives you direct control over compression level. Target size mode automatically finds the quality to achieve a specific file size in KB. Use target size when you need files under a certAIn limit.

faq.question: Will compression reduce image quality?
faq.answer: Compression involves a trade-off between file size and quality. At 70-80% quality, most people cannot see the difference. Target size mode automatically finds the quality for your size requirement.

faq.question: What's the format for compression?
faq.answer: WebP offers the compression (25-35% smaller than JPEG) with excellent quality. JPEG is for photos and has universal browser support. PNG is lossless but creates larger files.

faq.question: Are my images uploaded to your servers?
faq.answer: No! All compression happens directly in your browser using Canvas API technology. Your images never leave your device, ensuring complete privacy.

faq.question: How does the target size mode work?
faq.answer: Target size mode uses binary search to automatically find the highest quality setting that achieves your target file size. It tests multiple quality levels until it finds the optimal balance.

faq.question: Can I mix different image formats?
faq.answer: Yes! You can upload JPEG, PNG, and WebP images together. They'll all be converted to your chosen output format during compression.

faq.question: Is there a file size limit?
faq.answer: Each image can be up to 25MB. This limit is based on browser memory, not server restrictions (since we don't upload to servers).
